label: Special case - Type of, Sort of, Kind of

questions.question: Type of
questions.hint: Used to categorize or classify something into a specific group or category.
answer: What type of music do you like? I'm into classical and jazz.
This is a type of software designed for data analysis.
He prefers a type of exercise that's low-impact, like swimming or yoga.
There are several types of cuisines available at this restaurant, including Italian and Thai.
She collects a type of artwork known for its abstract style.

questions.question: Sort of
questions.hint: Used to express a degree of uncertainty or to describe something that is not exactly one thing but somewhat similar.
answer: It's sort of chilly today; you might need a light jacket.
He's sort of new to the job, so he might need some guidance.
The movie was sort of interesting but not exactly captivating.
This recipe is sort of like the one my grandmother used to make.
She's sort of an expert in the field, though not officially certified.

questions.question: Kind of
questions.hint: Used to indicate a general or approximate description, often expressing something that is not precisely one thing but close to it.
answer: I'm kind of tired today; I didn't sleep well last night.
That restaurant has a kind of rustic charm that's quite appealing.
He's kind of upset about the news, though he's trying to stay calm.
The new policy is kind of confusing, but I'm sure we'll get used to it.
Her dress is kind of similar to the one I saw at the boutique last week.

questions.question: As if / As though + subject + past tense (To express unreal comparison)

questions.question: I'd rather you + past tense (Polite suggestion or preference)

questions.question: Hardly had + subject + past participle + when + subject + verb

Hardly had she finished speaking when he interrupted.
Hardly had they arrived when the show began.

questions.question: I'm not sure if (Uncertainty or doubt)

questions.question: In case + subject + verb (As a precaution)

questions.question: The best thing about is that

questions.question: Would you mind + verb-ing (Polite request)

questions.question: Let me + base verb (Offering or deciding to do something)

questions.question: I'd like to + base verb (Polite way to express desire)
questions.hint: Structure: I'd like to + base verb

I'd like to share something important.

questions.question: I'm used to + noun/verb-ing (Describing habit or familiarity)

I'm used to cold weather.
I'm used to speaking in public.

questions.question: It's been a long time since + subject + verb (past)

It's been a long time since I played cricket.
It's been a long time since she visited us.

questions.question: As far as I know (To show personal knowledge)
questions.hint: Structure: As far as I know, + clause

questions.question: The reason why is because
questions.hint: Structure: The reason why + clause + is because + clause
answer: The reason why I left early is because I wasn't feeling well.
The reason why she's upset is because of the delay.
The reason why we're late is because of traffic.

questions.question: I was about to + base verb (To show something was just going to happen)
questions.hint: Structure: I was about to + base verb

I was about to leave the office.

questions.question: I'd rather + base verb

I'd rather speak to him directly.
I'd rather wait for a while.

questions.question: It's high time + subject + verb (past tense) (To say something should have happened already)
questions.hint: Structure: It's high time + subject + past tense verb

It's high time you took this seriously.
It's high time he made a decision.

questions.question: No matter + wh-word

No matter where you go, I'll support you.

questions.question: What if + subject + verb
questions.hint: Structure: What if + subject + verb (simple present/future)

questions.question: So that + subject + can/will
questions.hint: Structure: Clause + so that + subject + can/will + base verb

questions.question: I feel like + verb-ing (Talking about mood or desire)

questions.question: It looks like / It seems like

questions.question: Proactive: Creating or controlling a situation by causing something to happen rather than responding to it after it has happened

questions.question: Determined: Having made a firm decision and being resolved not to change it

questions.question: Flexible: Willing to change or compromise

questions.question: Patient: Able to accept or tolerate delays, problems, or suffering without becoming annoyed or anxious

questions.question: Persevering: Continuing in a course of action despite difficulty or delay in achieving success

questions.question: Resourceful: Having the ability to find quick and clever ways to overcome difficulties

questions.question: Respectful: Feeling or showing deference and respect

questions.question: Self-motivated: Motivated to do or achieve something because of one's own enthusiasm or interest, without needing pressure from others

questions.question: Sincere: Free from pretense or deceit; proceeding from genuine feelings

questions.question: Supportive: Providing encouragement or emotional help

questions.question: Tactful: Having or showing tact; able to deal with people in a sensitive manner

questions.question: Thorough: Taking great care to do something in a detailed and accurate way

questions.question: Due to
answer: The flight delay was due to inclement weather conditions at the destination airport.
The cancellation of the event was due to unforeseen circumstances beyond our control.
Her success in the project was due to her excellent leadership skills and dedication.

questions.question: Because

She succeeded in her exams because she studied diligently every day.
The event was canceled because of the heavy rainstorm.
He missed the deadline because his computer crashed unexpectedly.
The project failed because of a lack of communication among team members.

category: Join two parts of a sentence
label: Joins two parts of a sentence

questions.question: Coordinating Conjunctions
answer: And: I woke up early today, and I had a productive morning workout.
But: The weather was cloudy, but it turned out to be a beautiful day.
Or: You can have pancakes for breakfast, or you can enjoy a smoothie bowl.
Nor: She does not only excel in her studies, nor does she forget to help her friends.
Yet: It was a busy day at work, yet I managed to finish all my tasks on time.

questions.question: Subordinating Conjunctions
answer: Because: I feel great because I followed a healthy diet today.
Although: Although it was a hectic day, I found time to relax and read a book.
Since: Since I started practicing meditation, my stress levels have significantly decreased.
If: If I continue this routine, I'll achieve my fitness goals soon.
While: While I was working from home, I also managed to clean and organize my space.

questions.question: Correlative Conjunctions
answer: Either...or: You can either go for a walk in the park, or you can ride your bike around the neighborhood.
Neither...nor: Neither the rain nor the traffic could ruin my good mood today.
Not only...but also: Not only did I finish my project ahead of schedule, but I also helped a colleague with theirs.
Both...and: Both the morning meeting and the afternoon presentation went exceptionally well.
Whether...or: Whether I cook dinner or order takeout, tonight will be a relaxing evening.
